name: density
##Desnsity Chart
```{r eval=TRUE, out.width="75%", fig.align='center'}
library(ggplot2)
library(geomtextpath)
library(hrbrthemes)
data(SBCD)

p<-ggplot(SBCD, aes(x = Cell_Size_Uniformity, colour = Outcome, label = Outcome)) + geom_textdensity() + theme_bw() + guides(color = 'none')
p<- p+ labs(title = "Cell Size Uniformity Density Plot", x = "Cell Size Uniformity")
print(p)

```

name: conclusion
##Conclusion
The `Bland_Chromatin` variable was chosen as the dependent variable since it was the most normally distributed of the continuous variable options. `Cell_Size_Uniformity` had the highest correlation with the `Bland_Chromatin` variable and was then assigned as the independent variable for the logistic regression model. 

There is a correlation coeffient of .667 between the `Bland_Chromatin` and `Cell_Size_Uniformity` variables, signifying a strong correlation.

With a p-value very close to o (2e-16), there is statistical significance to the observed difference
